title: When will AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. (AMC), the parent company of AMC Theatres, file for bankruptcy?
preds: No change in my 100% "Not before 1 July 2021," but posting the below link.  After raising $587 million in new equity through stock sales on June 3, it seems hard to believe they will declare bankruptcy between now and July 1.[1] [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/03/amc-says-it-has-already-completed-share-offering-raises-587-million.html
this needs a follow up question on who wins the competition between shorters and longs.

Wanda Group sells almost all remaining stock in AMC Entertainment Holdings - Kansas City Business Journal - Philadelphia Business Journal
https://www.bizjournals.com/kansascity/news/2021/05/24/amc-entertainment-holdings-wanda-group-stock-sale.html
Mon, 24 May 2021 11:26:00 GMT AMC Stock: The Path Does Not Look Pretty - Seeking Alpha
https://seekingalpha.com/article/4429862-amc-entertainment-short-squeeze-the-path-does-not-look-pretty
Wed, 19 May 2021 06:54:00 GMT

AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. Cl A stock falls Friday, underperforms market - MarketWatch
https://www.marketwatch.com/story/amc-entertainment-holdings-inc-cl-a-stock-falls-friday-underperforms-market-01619814983-62e0113d04d3
Fri, 30 Apr 2021 20:36:00 GMT
AMC will have sufficient liquidity to carry through at least July to allow reopenings to kick in and taps of the debt markets will keep it afloat if needs be
Updating for time. Keeping 1% in bankruptcy- feels like the stock market movements are not driven by the most detailed analysis. However liquidity is king and they appear to be in a good place there.
AMC does need to file for Bankruptcy given bridge financing and the massive vaccine rollout. 0% chance it will file before 1 July 2021.
CEO was just paid huge bonus for 2020, NY and CA are starting to open, so unless there is a huge upturn in COVID or vaccines stop working, they should be safe until then.
AMC has recently announced that they got more money. They'll probably be fine for a while longer.
With the recent sale of new stock due to AMC's ballooning stock price, the company will have plenty of cash to ride out the short term wave through 1 July 2021.

With the recent surge in investment AMC will likely be able to survive past June through the sale of stock, raising new capital, and possible increases in ticket sales as the COVID-19 pandemic is brought under control. https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/29/amc-entertainment-explores-raising-new-capital-as-its-stock-surges-sources-say.html
They just got a huge influx of investment: https://www.cbsnews.com/news/amc-movie-theater-avoid-bankruptcy/

AMC now raising even more capital: https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/29/amc-entertainment-explores-raising-new-capital-as-its-stock-surges-sources-say.html If Gamestop were smart, it would be doing the same darn thing. Stock is a currency, and when your currency is overvalued, issue more of it!
Big jump in the stock price today. This means even market is discounting the possibility of bankruptcy. Luckily I own some AMC stocks.
Rounding down as I believe the number of companies that have raised the equivalent of a year's revenue and gone bankrupt in the following 6 months would be a fraction of a percentage point.

https://theweek.com/speedreads/963054/amc-theatres-says-raised-enough-money-that-imminent-bankruptcy-table
Looks good at the moment.  Holding back 1% because strange days.
Successful fundraising efforts appear to have significantly reduced this risk: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-01-25/amc-says-bankruptcy-off-the-table-after-raising-equity-loans
Updating my predictions based on successful capital raise of $900m, enough to survive until July even without guest numbers increasing. https://www.ft.com/content/08b09dd6-cd98-48e0-8cb3-270be3822072

If they run short on liquidity it seems pretty clear that Mudrick Capital and other investors can provide them the liquidity. Vaccine rollout has been slow but hospitalization is falling. We will get there.
https://investor.amctheatres.com/newsroom/news-details/2020/AMC-Entertainment-Holdings-Inc.-Secures-Commitment-for-100-Million-of-New-First-Lien-Debt-Financing-from-Mudrick-Capital-Management-L.P.-to-Bolster-AMCs-Near-Term-Liquidity/default.aspx
Big capital raise. Should make it through: https://www.wsj.com/articles/amc-nets-917-million-in-financing-to-ward-off-bankruptcy-11611574504

I have adjusted my forecast to indicate that it is less likely for AMC to file for bankruptcy before 01 April, and before 30 June.  The reason for my optimism (for AMC) is the continued COVID-19 vaccine roll-out, the fact that AMC still has ~760 million in market cap, and just this year (23 days) AMC stocks have risen by nearly 100%, including nearly 18% on Friday 22 January alone.

They just got all the funding they sought to raise for the short run.  Specifically, they borrowed $100 million with a secured note.  The first payment is not due until July 15th-- 15 days after the end of this question.  The company has also made a secondary stock option.   There is still some risk.   I read they could use bankruptcy to avoid some leases.  This seems to be a major concern.   However, I also read AMC borrowed a lot of money prior to the pandemic to upgrade their theaters.  Why would they try to get out of leases where they spent millions of their own money to upgrade the premises?  I see this as a possibility only if they run completely out of money prior to July 1, which now seems less likely.   https://www.msn.com/en-us/money/companies/amc-soars-37-after-issuing-100-million-in-debt-to-stave-off-bankruptcy/ar-BB1cTFbu https://www.yahoo.com/now/amc-shares-soar-more-than-30-181916769.html
The most likely reason would be the recent delay of blockbuster movie releases such as 007 No Time to Die, which has been delayed to Oct 2021.

Company filing stated cash of $320m at end of November 2020 and a cash burn rate of $125m per month in October & November. Would expect that to last until end of January/February without additional funding. Announced plans in December to raise $844m by selling stock, which would cover approx 6 further months if successfully in raising (which could take them beyond June). Slim chance that it would not be successful, as investors would be wiped out if they don't put up the cash, therefore likely that AMC will survive beyond June.
They've raised enough to get them through three months.

The use of European assets to prop up the US ones seems to be sufficient to fund the company through April. Executives appear insistent on avoiding bankruptcy. However, unless ticket sales resume or the company receives government assistance, bankruptcy is likely. I think there is a general feeling that the new Bond movie will spark revenues in April, so there will be a push to hold out until then. Therefore, I put the odds of before April very low. The risk comes from another surge in COVID cases. The theater chain won't survive another round of lock-downs in the Spring. But, the baseline assumption should be that vaccinations and new releases get things back on track (although a lower one than before the pandemic).

Reacting to successful share raising and rumours of further funding. Moved in line with consensus on surviving until July. I would consider being a bit higher given cash is king and they seem to be doing well at that, but still only rumours on the injection.  I think the consensus is wrong on timing though. Feels like if they can raise the funding now, unlikely to collapse between April and June and if they cannot, they may as well file early. Not going too skewed given you can see the fundraising being a long process and 1st March is arbitrary, plus taking into account the signal from the crowd.

AMC has raised $600M of the $750M they need to stay afloat till at least July. Despite the fact that AMCs creditors have urged it to restructure its debt(i.e. declare bankruptcy), it seems likely AMC will have gained enough money to avoid bankruptcy until July with the sale of new stock. This line from the linked article is particularly telling "Aron (AMC CEO) is close enough to nabbing the funds that he has refused to engage in talks with lenders about bankruptcy financing, the sources added."  https://nypost.com/2021/01/07/amc-getting-closer-to-avoiding-bankruptcy-until-summer/

Bankruptcy for AMC appears to be inevitable thanks to the dramatic shift in movie releases resulting from the COVID pandemic.  Yet AMC's CEO has continually refused to accept bankruptcy as a near term option.  He has commenced numerous fundraising efforts designed to maintain solvency until summer when Hollywood is expected to continue releasing delayed blockbusters and when COVID vaccinations should be available to the general public. On January 7, the NY Post wrote about AMC's recent fundraising success. https://nypost.com/2021/01/07/amc-getting-closer-to-avoiding-bankruptcy-until-summer/ They have raised almost $600 million of their $750 million goal in January.  With those kinds of funds, AMC can likely remain solvent until the summer.  At that point, the situation regarding COVID and Hollywood movie releases should be far more clear.   With AMC doing everything to avoid bankruptcy, and with fundraising success, it is highly unlikely that they will declare bankruptcy before 1 April unless a lucrative offer emerges.  The bigger question is whether or not their newly acquired funds would run out before 1 July.  Yet given the potential for this summer to offer a strong increase in sales, coupled with the AMC CEO continually fighting to stave off bankruptcy, it appears that such a decision will be pushed back beyond 1 July.

Early split based on the current position of the company to try and push through 2021.  If their forecast of $750M required is accurate, the $200M raised should get them to about the end of March, and given the CEO's unwillingness to file for Chapter 11 at this point, it's unlikely he will suddenly announce it's time to file for bankruptcy in April as this cash injection dwindles.  https://www.fool.com/millionacres/real-estate-investing/articles/amc-raised-200-million-in-december-will-this-save-it/
It depends on how much stimulus money Biden admin will pass.
Vaccine rollout+people thinking they can go back to normal life (incorrect)+Top Gun II release = lifeline for AMC
I want to be at 20/20/60, but I'm updating a little bit on the current aggregate.

With the distribution of a vaccine for COVID-19, I suspect that there are enough rich people, with deep enough pockets to ride this one out for a few months. Particularly with some of the new blockbuster movies that were due to be released soon after COVID-19 hit the world.

They seem to have european odean assets that can get several months cash for.  I think there main liability is rent, and presumably they can stiff some people.  I don't see bond expirations for several years.  Stimulus might be helfpful.  Stock is trading at clearly distressed levels though.

With its shares at records lows in the first week of 2021, AMC is in relatively dire straits. Prior to the pandemic, it was on a spending spree buying competitor theaters and renovating existing locations. This expenditure is coming back to bite the company as theaters have remained unprofitable due to covid restrictions and public perception of risk.  The company continues to seek a lifeline, but it is likely it will need to restructure through bankruptcy. This is compounded by the fact that it is ineligible for some forms of governmental aid. If AMC can figure out how to stay operational through the spring, it will be unlikely that it will declare during the Apil-May-June timeframe as it anticipates a summer resurgence in ticket sales due to weather, lockdown fatigue, and vaccine availability. If this rebound happens it is possible that it moves into the second half of the year on better financial footing.  https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/05/coronavirus-amc-seeks-550-million-as-stock-closes-at-record-low.html

studios postponing major blockbusters until mid-2021; reduced ticket sales from some studios releasing major movies in theaters and on streaming platforms simultaneously; the likelihood of an available vaccine not being widely available until mid-2021; recent company releases that they are close to meeting the $750 million goal that will prevent bankruptcy until the summer through selling shares; working on rent deferral program. In December, commercial bankruptcy filings increased 29% compared to 2019.

They have the option of selling assets in Europe as a last resort. The Wanda Group which owns AMC isn't keen on wiping out their entire equity by filing for bankruptcy. Also they had 400mn$ of cash in Sept and the monthly burn seems to be close to 110mn$ .They have raised 200mn$. So that means they are close to 300mn $ still. They have to recalculate debt covenants in Q2 (6 times Ebitda i don't see that happening too). Could there be another covenant waiver I don't know
https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.fool.com/amp/earnings/call-transcripts/2020/11/03/amc-entertainment-holdings-amc-q3-2020-earnings-ca/ Also some rumor of a successful round of fund raise. https://www.google.com/amp/s/nypost.com/2021/01/07/amc-getting-closer-to-avoiding-bankruptcy-until-summer/amp/

“We need to raise more, but we’re working hard to do that and we’ve laid out a plan and a blueprint to get there,” [AMC CEO Adam Aron] said (on 1/7/21). “Whether we get there or not, only time will tell.” (Source: https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/05/coronavirus-amc-seeks-550-million-as-stock-closes-at-record-low.html) ..Seems like an accurate summary of their current situation. A new, more transmissible COVID-19 variant (becoming more common) may likely prolong theater attendance woes. (https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/covid-variant-contagious-spread/2021/01/06/73a1b716-4fc2-11eb-83e3-322644d82356_story.html)
Unless they get investment, they'll run out of money before April.

Worth about $7 pre covid, now at about $2. Probably worthless if they go into bankruptcy. Very simply that would imply very top end marker expectation for survival at something like 27% ( could be higher if the non bankruptcy value is below $7, could be lower if people expect some chance of residual value if they do go into bankruptcy.  It does look like a business in considerable trouble, but the shares have not plunged on the offering and they got a recent cash injection, plus presumably someone gave them confidence to announce the share sale. Overall I think 30/15/55 makes sense. Market analysis was simplistic plus it just felt to low for a business with some very real issues even post covid. In terms of timing if the financings fail, feels like they would effectively be forced to file.
